I'm really struggling. My husband just got home from the hospital, and his mood is all over the place. He was initially angry, then he seemed to be doing wonderfully, but now he's slipped into this deep depression and feels hopeless.

It sounds like you and your husband are going through a very challenging time. It's understandable to feel overwhelmed by these rapid changes in his mood, especially after a hospital stay. I'm here to support you both through this. It's important to ensure he gets the follow-up care he needs. Does he have a therapist or counselor he was seeing?
Yes, he does have a therapist he was seeing before the hospitalization. But since he's been home, we haven't been in touch with them.

Reaching out to his therapist as soon as possible would be a good step. They can provide the necessary support and guidance during this time. It's also beneficial to let your support system of friends, family, or clergy know about the situation so they can offer their support. How does that sound to you?
That makes sense. I'm just worried about how to keep him safe. He's mentioned feeling suicidal before, and I'm scared it might happen again.

Your concern is completely valid and it's important to take any mention of suicide very seriously. Ensuring his safety is a priority. Removing any means that could be harmful, especially firearms if you have any in the home, can make a significant difference. Have you taken any steps towards this?
We don't have firearms, but I hadn't thought about other things around the house. I'll need to look into that.

It's a good idea to minimize access to anything he might use to harm himself. It's also helpful to have someone with him, if possible, during this vulnerable time. Your support system can play a role here, taking turns to be with him. How do you feel about discussing a safety plan with him?
I'm not sure how to bring it up. I don't want to make things worse or upset him.

It's understandable to feel hesitant. Approaching the topic with care and empathy is key. Let him know you're there for him, you care, and you're concerned about his well-being. It's about ensuring his safety because you love him. Would you like some guidance on how to have this conversation?
Yes, please. I could use all the help I can get.

Of course. Start by choosing a calm and comfortable time to talk, without distractions. Express your concerns using 'I' statements, like 'I've noticed...' and 'I feel worried when...', to avoid making him feel blamed. Ask open-ended questions to encourage him to share his thoughts and feelings. And remember, it's okay to ask directly about suicidal thoughts. Many people fear this might 'put the idea into their head,' but it actually provides a sense of relief that someone is willing to talk about it openly. How does that sound?
It sounds doable. I'm just hoping it makes a difference.

It's a step towards understanding and supporting him better. And remember, if you believe an attempt is imminent, don't hesitate to call emergency services. It's also a good idea to have the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline number handy: 1-800-273-8255. They can help with creating a specific safety plan too. You're not alone in this. How are you holding up through all of this?
It's been tough, but knowing there are steps I can take helps. Thank you for the advice and support.

You're welcome. Remember to take care of yourself as well. Supporting someone through such a difficult time can be draining, and your well-being is just as important. If you need more support or have any questions, please feel free to reach out. Be well.

questionText: After my fiancé cheated on me because of a miscommunication, I pulled myself away from him.    Now he says all he wants is be with me. I'm pushing him away mentally now because he cheated on me again. I make plans with him that I don't keep. I really do love him still and I care about him. Should I give home one more chance?
answerText: People don't cheat bc of miscommunication.   People cheat bc they feel diminished regard for their partner.You pulling away doesn't explain his behavior.If the two of you still were a couple at the time he cheated on you, then there were many alternatives he cold have taken besides disrespecting you.Try to understand whether you are satisfied and happy in the relationship.  Your actions sound as though you are not either of these.Whether or not you decide to be together again many depend too on if the trust you had in him is restored.  Do you feel you can trust him again?If the two of discuss your relationship then if you don't trust him right now and the both of you talk about your dynamics, then tell him about your feelings.Trust is foundational to feeling safe and happy in a relationship.

messages.content: Hello, how are you doing, how can I help you today?

I've been struggling a lot lately. After my fiancé cheated on me because of what he called a miscommunication, I've found myself pulling away from him. But now, he's saying all he wants is to be with me. It's confusing because he cheated on me again. I keep making plans with him that I don't follow through on. Deep down, I still love and care about him. I'm just not sure if I should give him another chance.

It sounds like you're going through a very challenging time, feeling torn between your love for your fiancé and the hurt from his actions. It's understandable to feel confused and to have mixed emotions about giving him another chance. It's important to acknowledge that people don't cheat because of miscommunication; they cheat because they choose to, which can reflect a diminished regard for their partner. How are you feeling about your relationship with him right now?

I'm just so conflicted. Sometimes, I feel like I want to be with him because we've shared so many good times. But then, I remember what he did, and I feel so disrespected and hurt. I'm not sure if I can trust him again, and that scares me.

Feeling conflicted in such a situation is completely normal. Trust is foundational to feeling safe and happy in a relationship. If trust is broken, it can be very difficult to move forward. It's also understandable to feel scared about the possibility of not being able to trust him again. Reflecting on whether you are satisfied and happy in the relationship, aside from these incidents, might help clarify your feelings. Have you been able to discuss your feelings and concerns with him openly?
We've tried talking about it, but I don't think he truly understands how deeply his actions hurt me. It feels like he thinks we can just move past it without really addressing the underlying issues.

It's crucial for both partners to feel heard and understood, especially when trying to heal from infidelity. It sounds like there might be a need for a deeper conversation about the impact of his actions on you and the relationship. Communicating your feelings and the need for understanding each other's perspectives might be a step towards deciding whether you can rebuild the trust that's been damaged. How do you feel about trying to have another conversation with him, this time laying out more clearly the depth of your feelings and the importance of addressing these issues together?

That makes sense. I guess I've been avoiding that kind of conversation because I'm afraid of the outcome. But you're right, we need to have a real talk if there's any chance of us moving forward. I'm just not sure how to start.

It's completely understandable to feel afraid of the outcome. Starting such a conversation can be daunting, but it's also a courageous step towards healing, whether together or apart. It might help to start by expressing your feelings without blame, using 'I' statements to communicate how his actions have affected you. It's also important to express what you need from him and the relationship moving forward. Would you like some guidance on how to structure this conversation?
Yes, that would be really helpful. I want to make sure I'm communicating my feelings clearly without it turning into an argument.

Absolutely, keeping the conversation constructive is important. Begin by setting a calm, undistracted time and place to talk. You might start with something like, 'I've been feeling a lot of hurt and confusion about what happened, and it's important for me to express how it's affected me and our relationship.' Encourage him to share his perspective too, but make it clear that understanding each other's feelings and working through the issues together is crucial for moving forward. How does that sound?
It sounds like a good plan. I'm nervous, but I know it's necessary. Thank you for helping me see that and for giving me a way to approach it.

You're very welcome. It's normal to feel nervous about such conversations, but remember, it's a step towards clarity and healing, no matter the outcome. You're taking a brave step in addressing this. Please, feel free to reach out if you need more support or if you'd like to talk about how the conversation went. I'm here for you.
Thank you so much. I really appreciate your support and guidance. I'll definitely keep you updated.
I look forward to hearing from you, and I'm here whenever you need. Take care of yourself, and remember, you deserve to be in a relationship where you feel valued and respected.

questionText: After receiving counseling, we have been told my husband has a black and white personality disorder. When I offer compromises in our disagreements, he does not seem to understand. We cannot resolve conflict because he only sees things as black or white. My husband has asked that we go to counseling this time. In the past, it has been my suggestion. We are thinking of going to a marriage mediator this time because there are financial issues that need to be resolved. He cannot see the whole picture when I attempt to explain my side to him.
answerText: I never heard of a marriage mediator before.Since you already went to counseling and the therapist observed your husband's tendency to see black and white in life, and because counseling functions on a deeper level than a mediator generally does, a marriage mediator sounds like a step backwards.Why not go to a financial mediator?This would satisfy your husband's black white outlook and may satisfy you too because no emotions are expected in financial discussion and the relationship suffers from an expectations surrounding emotion.

messages.content: Hello, how are you doing, how can I help you today?

I've been feeling quite stressed lately. My husband and I have been facing some issues. We were told he has a black and white personality disorder, and it's been challenging to resolve conflicts because of this.

It sounds like you're going through a tough time trying to communicate and resolve conflicts with your husband due to his black and white thinking. It's good that you're seeking help. You mentioned considering going to a marriage mediator this time, especially for financial issues. Can you tell me more about that?

Yes, in the past, it was usually me suggesting counseling, but this time he suggested it. However, we thought maybe a marriage mediator would help, especially since we have some financial disagreements that we can't seem to resolve either.

It's encouraging to hear that your husband is taking the initiative this time. It shows a willingness to work on the issues together. Regarding the idea of a marriage mediator, it's an interesting approach. However, considering the previous counseling where your husband's black and white thinking was highlighted, a financial mediator might be more beneficial. It could address the financial disagreements directly without the emotional complexities. What are your thoughts on this?

I hadn't thought about a financial mediator specifically. I guess I'm just worried that if we only focus on the financial aspect, we might ignore the underlying emotional issues. But it does make sense, especially if it helps us move forward with at least one of our problems.

It's perfectly normal to feel concerned about not addressing the emotional issues directly. However, resolving the financial disagreements could provide some relief and might even create a more stable foundation to address the emotional and relational aspects later. It's about taking one step at a time. Would you feel comfortable discussing this option with your husband?
I think so. It's a practical approach, and it might actually work for us. I appreciate your insight on this. It's given me a new perspective on how to tackle our issues.

I'm glad to hear that you're feeling a bit more hopeful about finding a way forward. Remember, it's important to keep the lines of communication open with your husband and to approach each step as a team. If you ever feel like you need more support or wish to explore other options, please don't hesitate to reach out.
Thank you, I will definitely keep that in mind. And I might take you up on that offer for more support in the future. I appreciate your help today.
You're welcome! I'm here to support you. Take care, and I wish you and your husband the best as you work through these challenges together.

questionText: All my friends have either hooked up or had a girlfriend but me. I try to be happy for them, but I get really upset every time they hook up.
answerText: If you mean “hooked up” as having sex with no care for the person, and you’d like a girlfriend, then realize relationships require more complex alignment with a partner than being a sex buddy.Pay attention to all your feelings toward a girl so that you’ll approach someone who attracts you for reasons in addition to sexual allure.Also, the process of knowing someone takes much more time than only to sleep with someone.Have patience and kindness toward yourself while you get to know the qualities which attract you to a potential girlfriend.

messages.content: Hello, how are you doing, how can I help you today?
I've been feeling really down lately. All my friends seem to be in relationships or hooking up, and I'm just not. I try to be happy for them, but it's tough.

It sounds like you're feeling left out and maybe a bit lonely seeing your friends in relationships or hooking up. It's understandable to feel this way. Would you like to talk more about these feelings?
Yeah, I do. It's like, I'm happy for them, but then I feel really upset and wonder why it's not happening for me. It's confusing.

It's completely natural to have those conflicting feelings. You're happy for your friends but also feeling upset about your own situation. It's important to acknowledge these feelings and not be too hard on yourself. Have you thought about what kind of relationship you're looking for?
I guess I haven't really thought about it much. I mean, I'd like a girlfriend, but I don't just want to hook up. I want something more meaningful, you know?

Wanting a meaningful relationship is a significant and valid feeling. It's about connecting on a deeper level, not just physically. It's good that you're aware of what you're looking for. Remember, forming a meaningful relationship takes time and is about finding someone you're truly compatible with, not just about physical attraction. How do you feel about giving yourself time and patience in this process?
I understand that it takes time, but it's hard to be patient. Especially when it seems like everyone else isn't having trouble finding someone.

It's completely understandable to feel impatient and to compare your journey to others. It's human nature. But everyone's path to finding a meaningful relationship is unique. It might be helpful to focus on what you can control, like exploring your interests and meeting new people, not just for a relationship but to enrich your own life. How does that sound?
That makes sense. I guess I've been so focused on what I don't have that I've ignored what I could be doing for myself.

It's a common thing to do, but recognizing it is a great first step. Focusing on yourself and what makes you happy can lead to meeting someone who shares your interests and values. What are some things you enjoy doing?
I like reading, playing video games, and sometimes hiking. I haven't done much of those lately, though.

Those are great hobbies! Engaging in activities you enjoy can improve your mood and open up opportunities to meet like-minded people. Maybe you could join a book club or a gaming group, or even a hiking club. What do you think?
That could be interesting. I haven't really thought about joining any groups, but it might be nice to meet people with similar interests.

It could be a great way to expand your social circle and potentially meet someone who's looking for a meaningful relationship as well. Plus, it's an opportunity to do more of what you love. Would you like some help looking into groups or clubs you might be interested in?
Yeah, that would be helpful. I'm not sure where to start.

I can certainly provide some resources and suggestions for finding groups that match your interests. Remember, it's about taking steps towards what makes you happy and fulfilled. How do you feel about moving forward with this approach?
I feel a bit more hopeful, actually. It's nice to think about focusing on what I enjoy and maybe that leading somewhere good. Thanks for suggesting it.

You're welcome! I'm glad to hear you're feeling more hopeful. Remember, it's okay to seek happiness and fulfillment in your own life, and it's okay to take time in finding a meaningful relationship. I'm here to support you through this journey. Is there anything else you'd like to discuss today?
No, I think that's it for now. I really appreciate the talk and the advice. It's given me a lot to think about.
I'm glad I could help. Remember, you're not alone, and it's perfectly okay to reach out whenever you need to talk. Take care, and I look forward to our next session.

questionText: All we do is argue. We never agree on anything.
answerText: Simply, Yes!Just because you argue, does not mean your marriage is not worth it. Couples disagree. They are different people from different worlds with different likes and dislikes. Trying to mesh these different worlds is tough, but does not mean you don’t need to not be married.There are reasons why couples don’t get along. Finding out why you cannot compromise and working towards similar goals can help. Talking about what you really want out of the marriage and relationship may show y’all how much your relationship goals are similar. Then you can build upon that.Learning communication skills, listening skills and ways to improve your ability to express self without anger can help.

messages.content: Hello, how are you doing, how can I help you today?
I've been feeling really frustrated lately. My partner and I, we just can't seem to get along. All we do is argue.
It sounds like you're going through a really tough time. Arguing constantly can be exhausting. Can you tell me a bit more about what you usually disagree on?
It's about everything and anything. From small decisions like what to have for dinner, to big ones like financial planning. We never seem to find common ground.
It must feel like you're both coming from completely different places, making it hard to see eye to eye. Despite these arguments, how do you feel about your relationship overall?
Honestly, I love my partner very much, but these constant disagreements make me doubt our future together. It's draining.

Feeling drained and doubting the future of your relationship is natural when disagreements are frequent. It's important to remember that all couples have disagreements because everyone is an individual with their own preferences. What matters is how you navigate these differences. Have you both ever discussed your overarching goals and desires for the relationship?
Not really, we usually end up arguing before we can get to that point. It feels like we're stuck in a loop.

It sounds like communication has become a cycle of arguing without reaching an understanding. Breaking that cycle could be key to moving forward. Learning how to express yourselves without anger and actively listening to each other can be a good start. Would you be open to exploring ways to improve your communication skills together?
Yes, I think we're both tired of arguing. I just don't know where to start.

Starting can be the hardest part, but acknowledging that there's a problem and being willing to work on it is a significant first step. There are many ways to improve communication, such as setting aside a calm time to talk, using 'I feel' statements instead of accusations, and learning to listen without preparing your rebuttal. How does that sound?
That sounds like something we could try. I just hope we can actually stick to it without falling back into our old patterns.

Change takes time and effort from both sides, and it's okay to have setbacks as long as you keep moving forward. Remember, the goal isn't to never argue, but to learn how to handle disagreements in a way that strengthens your relationship rather than weakening it. Would you like some guidance on how to set up this new communication framework?
Yes, please. I really want to make this work.

Great! Let's start by planning a time when you both are relaxed and not rushed. During this time, share with each other your desires and expectations for the relationship without criticism or interruption. It's about understanding each other's perspective and building from there. I can provide you with some guidelines and exercises to help with this. How does that sound?
It sounds like a plan. I'm willing to try anything at this point.
I'm here to support you through this process. Remember, the fact that you're seeking ways to improve your relationship shows a lot of commitment and love. Let's take this one step at a time.
Thank you. I appreciate your help and understanding. It feels good to have a plan moving forward.

questionText: An organization admitted to implanting thoughts in my head with technologies. The study was to implant a fantasy other people are having, but to me, it's a nightmare. I lost my kids, my job, and all that. I was an unwilling participant. I no longer trust a therapist. I'm too afraid to go under hypnosis or anything.
answerText: Given your experience of being imposed upon against your will, and all the personal and professional loss that has come since, your fear of what will happen if you undergo treatment and trust a therapist is understandable. There is no technique or pill that can guarantee these thoughts will go away or be reversed, however, there are things that you can do which may help you to change your relationship to the thoughts and to the distress that they cause. I understand that working with a therapist sounds risky, given your experiences, and at the same time a good therapist may be a beneficial resource in helping you deal with the intrusive thoughts, cope with and alleviate the stress that they create, and perhaps even lead to the alleviation of the thoughts themselves. A therapist may also be able to help you discover strategies to work towards any goals you have around reconnecting with your children and working again. If therapy feels too unsafe at the moment, I would recommend looking into workbooks on how to deal with intrusive thoughts and coping with stress. Some popular approaches that you may want to look into are mindfulness techniques, Acceptance and Commitment Therapy, or Cognitive Behavioral Therapy. You may even be able to find some of these resources at a library, if affordability is an obstacle.

messages.content: Hello, how are you doing, how can I help you today?
I've been struggling a lot lately. An organization admitted to implanting thoughts in my head with technologies. It was supposed to be a fantasy, but it's been nothing but a nightmare for me.

That sounds incredibly difficult and distressing. To have your autonomy compromised in such a way, and then to suffer such profound consequences in your life, must be very hard to come to terms with. I'm here to listen and support you through this.
Thank you, but I'm not sure if I can trust therapy again. After what happened, I'm too afraid to go under hypnosis or anything like that. I've lost my kids, my job... everything.

Your fear and reluctance to trust therapy again are completely understandable given what you've been through. Losing so much and feeling betrayed in such a fundamental way would make anyone wary of opening up again. Let's take things at a pace you're comfortable with, with no pressure to undergo any treatments you're not ready for.
I appreciate that, but I feel stuck. These thoughts they implanted... they're always there, haunting me. I don't know how to get rid of them.

Feeling stuck and haunted by these thoughts sounds incredibly challenging. While there's no instant solution to remove these thoughts, there are ways to change your relationship with them and reduce the distress they cause. Would you be open to exploring some non-invasive strategies together, at your own pace?
Maybe... I just don't want to feel like this anymore. But I'm scared of making things worse.

It's perfectly normal to feel scared about the possibility of things getting worse. What we can aim for is to find gentle and non-threatening ways to help you cope better with these thoughts and the feelings they bring up. We can start with something simple like mindfulness techniques, which don't require you to delve into anything you're not comfortable with. How does that sound?
Mindfulness... I've heard of it but never really tried it. I guess it couldn't hurt to learn more about it.

That's a great start. Mindfulness is about being present in the moment and observing your thoughts and feelings without judgment. It can be a helpful tool in managing intrusive thoughts. I can guide you through some basic exercises to begin with, and we can take it from there. How would you feel about giving it a try?
Okay, I'm willing to try it. I just want some relief from these thoughts.

I'm glad to hear you're open to trying it. Remember, this is about taking small steps and finding what works for you. There's no pressure to get it right immediately. Let's work together at a pace that feels comfortable for you. We can start with some simple exercises and see how you feel.
Thank you. I appreciate your understanding and patience. It means a lot to me right now.

You're very welcome. It's important to me that you feel supported and understood. Whenever you're ready, we can start with some mindfulness exercises or explore other options. I'm here to support you through this journey.

questionText: Any time my family and friends are in an altercation, I’m the one who steps in. I’m the one they call to fight for them. I do this even though I have a tough time trusting the people I’m fighting for. I’m only in my early 20s.
answerText: You could be protective because of things that happened in your past or in the past of the people that you are protecting. A lot of us have natural instincts that we do not want other people to be in pain. For other people, conflict is just hard to watch and/or listen to.As for having a tough time trusting them, that could also relate to past events between you and these other people or it could relate to the conflict that you mentioned. It can be difficult to trust someone deeply when you don't know when the next big fight or argument is going to start.The next time you step in for someone, consider asking yourself what is making you do that? What are you feeling in the moment?

messages.content: Hello, how are you doing, how can I help you today?
I've been feeling really overwhelmed lately. Any time there's an issue within my family or among my friends, I'm the one everyone expects to step in and sort it out. It's exhausting.

It sounds like you're carrying a heavy burden, feeling responsible for resolving conflicts among your loved ones. That must be quite challenging for you, especially at a young age. Can you tell me a bit more about how this makes you feel?
It's like I'm constantly on edge, waiting for the next problem to pop up. And the truth is, I don't always trust the people I'm fighting for, which makes it even harder.

It's understandable to feel on edge and conflicted, especially when you're putting so much of yourself into these situations without fully trusting those you're helping. Trust is a fundamental part of our relationships, and it can be deeply unsettling when it's shaken. Do you think your difficulty in trusting them is related to past experiences?
Maybe. I've been let down before, so now I guess I'm just wary. But I can't help stepping in when I see them in trouble.

It's a natural instinct to want to protect others from pain, especially those close to us. Your protective nature is a testament to your character, even more so because you act despite your reservations. Reflecting on why you step in, even when it's difficult, could offer some insights into your feelings and motivations. What do you think drives you to intervene?
I'm not sure. I hate seeing people in conflict, and I feel like if I don't do something, no one will. It's like I'm the glue holding everything together.

Feeling like the glue in relationships can be a heavy load to carry. It shows how much you care and your willingness to maintain harmony, even at your own expense. It's important to remember that it's okay to set boundaries for yourself and to consider your own well-being. Have you thought about ways to manage this responsibility so it feels less overwhelming?
Not really. I don't even know where I'd start with setting boundaries. I'm afraid of letting people down.

Setting boundaries doesn't mean you care any less about your family and friends. It's about caring for yourself too. It can start with small steps, like giving yourself permission to say no or asking for time to think before you respond to a request for help. How does that sound to you?
That makes sense, but it sounds scary. I'm not used to putting myself first.

It's natural to feel apprehensive about trying something new, especially when it involves changing long-standing patterns of behavior. Remember, setting boundaries is a form of self-respect and it's a process. It's okay to take it one step at a time. Is there a small step you feel comfortable trying as a start?
Maybe I could start by not immediately saying yes when someone asks for help. I could take some time to think about whether I can really handle it.

That sounds like a very reasonable and manageable first step. Taking time to consider your own capacity and needs is a healthy practice. How do you feel about trying this approach the next time you're faced with a situation?
I'm willing to give it a try. I know it won't be easy, but I think it's necessary for my own peace of mind.
I'm glad to hear you're open to trying it. Remember, it's a journey, and it's okay to seek support along the way. I'm here for you. How else can I support you in this process?
Just knowing I can talk about this and not be judged is really helpful. Thanks for listening and understanding.
You're very welcome. It's important to have a space where you feel heard and understood. Please feel free to share anything else on your mind, whenever you're ready. I'm here to support you.

questionText: Any time things get heated, the past gets brought up. I raise my voice at her to try to get a point across. She asks open-ended questions but always has to turn my own answer against me. She's seven months pregnant. I have drank in the past, but I'm not dependent on alcohol—I only drink at social events.
answerText: Have you tried to talk about the subjects of the past, in the present at a time in which there is no heat between the two of you?Since your gf would like to resolve situations from the past the best way to do so would be to talk about them.  The more you try to avoid certain subjects the more likely they will come up between you at worse possible moments.If you can get ahead of the pattern of old topics coming up without your control, then try scheduling a discussion about them.  This by itself will show your gf you care about what she cares about and this may be one quality she would feel good about.

messages.content: Hello, how are you doing, how can I help you today?
I've been feeling really frustrated lately. Any time things get heated between me and my girlfriend, the past just keeps coming up.

It sounds like you're finding it challenging to move past certain issues. It's understandable that this would be frustrating. Can you tell me a bit more about what happens when the past is brought up?
Well, I tend to raise my voice to try to get my point across. And she, she asks these open-ended questions but then seems to turn my answers against me. It's like we're stuck in this loop.

Raising your voice and feeling like your words are turned against you can definitely make you feel stuck and unheard. It's important for both partners to feel listened to and understood. Have you both tried discussing these topics when things are calm, outside of a heated moment?
Not really, it seems like we only talk about this stuff when we're already upset. And, she's seven months pregnant, which makes me even more worried about our arguments.

That's a significant concern, especially with a baby on the way. It's crucial to find a way to communicate effectively and calmly. Have you thought about setting aside a specific time to talk about these issues, when both of you are feeling more relaxed and open?

I haven't, but I'm not sure how to bring that up without starting another argument. And there's also the thing with alcohol. I've drank in the past, but I'm not dependent on it. I only drink at social events.

It's understandable to be concerned about initiating a potentially difficult conversation. However, expressing your intention to improve your communication for the sake of your relationship and your growing family can be a good place to start. Regarding alcohol, it's good to hear that you have control over it. It might be helpful to discuss any concerns she has about it in a calm setting as well. What do you think?
That makes sense. I just want us to be okay, especially before the baby arrives. I guess I'm just scared of making things worse.

Your concern shows that you care deeply about your relationship and your future as a family. It's okay to be scared, but facing these issues together, openly and calmly, can strengthen your bond. How do you feel about trying to schedule a time with her to talk about everything, using 'I' statements to express your feelings without placing blame?
I think that could help. I'm just not sure how to start, but I know I need to try something different.

Starting is often the hardest part, but your willingness to try is a great first step. Perhaps you could begin by acknowledging the current communication challenges and expressing your desire to work through them together for the well-being of your family. I'm here to support you through this process. How does that sound?
It sounds like a plan. I'm nervous, but I know it's important. Thank you for helping me see that.

You're welcome. It's normal to feel nervous, but remember, this is about building a stronger foundation for your family. I believe in your ability to make positive changes. Please feel free to reach out if you need further support or guidance.

questionText: As I was growing up, my mother and father always fought. With that, I grew trust issues. I think it's going to affect my relationship now and end it sooner then I want to. I try not to let it affect me, but I can’t.
answerText: If you thing your trust issues are going to end or affect your relationship it will because you are being baggage from your parents into this relationship.  Don't allow their problems to become your problem.  You didn't mention that your partner in your present relationship have done anything to make you not trust them.  Like in the court of law, if no evidence....find not guilty.  Don't make them pay the consequences as if guilty of your parents unhealthy behavior.

messages.content: Hello, how are you doing, how can I help you today?

I've been feeling really anxious about my relationship lately. Growing up, my parents always fought, and it's left me with some pretty deep trust issues. I'm worried it's going to ruin my current relationship.

It sounds like you're carrying a heavy weight from your past experiences, and it's understandable that those feelings are causing you anxiety in your current relationship. It's important to recognize those feelings. Can you tell me a bit more about how these trust issues are manifesting in your relationship?

Well, I find myself constantly doubting my partner's intentions. Even when there's no real reason to, I get paranoid they're going to hurt me like I saw my parents hurt each other. It's like I'm waiting for something bad to happen.

It sounds like those past experiences with your parents have created a sort of template for how you view relationships, leading to fear and doubt even in the absence of any real threats from your partner. It's a natural response to want to protect yourself from potential pain. Have you been able to talk to your partner about these feelings?
I've tried, but I'm scared they won't understand. I don't want to burden them with my issues or make them think they're doing something wrong when they're not.

Sharing your feelings with your partner can indeed feel daunting, especially when those feelings are rooted in deep-seated issues from your past. However, opening up about your fears and vulnerabilities can also strengthen your bond. It's about framing it in a way that lets them know you're working through these issues and that you value their support. How do you feel about approaching the conversation from that angle?
That might be a good idea. I just don't know how to start that conversation without making it sound like I don't trust them because of something they did.

Starting such conversations can be challenging, but it can help to begin by affirming your trust and love for them. You might say something like, 'I really value our relationship and trust you. I'm working through some personal issues related to trust, stemming from my past, not from anything you've done. I hope we can work through this together.' How does that sound?
That sounds doable. I think they'll understand if I put it that way. I really don't want my past to mess this up. Thanks for helping me see there's a way to communicate this.

I'm glad to hear that you're feeling more optimistic about communicating your feelings. Remember, it's a sign of strength to be vulnerable and seek support, both from your partner and others you trust. Is there anything else you'd like to discuss or any other support you need right now?
No, I think that's it for now. I feel a lot better having talked this through. I'll try talking to my partner soon. Thank you for your guidance.
You're welcome. I'm here for you whenever you need to talk or explore these feelings further. Remember, it's a process, and it's okay to take it one step at a time. Take care.

questionText: As a child, my parents injured my brother, so they went to prison. I was there when he had gotten hurt, but I can't seem to remember. I also can't remember being with them quite well. It's a blur.
answerText: It's important to know that there are counselors who are trained in working with survivors of trauma and you can get help.  The "blur" in your memories is your brain's attempt to protect you from the experiences in your past.  To recover them can be a slow process done by a trained professional that you trust.  When you are ready and feel safe, those memories can be recovered and can be integrated with other memories.  This will help to lessen the potency of the memory, help to make sense of what has happened, and allow you to begin the healing process.  Check into therapist who are trained in EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing).

messages.content: Hello, how are you doing, how can I help you today?

I've been struggling with something from my past. As a child, my parents injured my brother, and they went to prison for it. I was there when it happened, but I can't seem to remember it or much about being with them. Everything's just a blur.

I'm really sorry to hear that you've been carrying this weight with you. It sounds like a very difficult and painful part of your past. It's not uncommon for our minds to shield us from traumatic memories by making them blurry or hard to access. I'm here to support you through this.
It's just so frustrating. Sometimes I feel like I'm supposed to remember, to understand what happened, but I can't.

It's understandable that you're feeling frustrated. The process of dealing with, and potentially recovering, memories can be very challenging. It's important to approach it gently and with support. Your brain is trying to protect you in its own way. When you're ready, and with the guidance of a professional you trust, it's possible to explore these memories safely.
How can I start to remember? Or should I even try?

Deciding to explore these memories is a very personal decision and one that requires careful consideration. There are therapists trained in working with survivors of trauma who can guide you through this process. Techniques like EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing) have been helpful for many in recovering and integrating traumatic memories. It's about finding a pace that feels right for you and ensuring you feel safe throughout the process.
I've heard of EMDR but never really understood what it is or how it could help me.

EMDR is a form of therapy designed to help people recover from trauma and reduce the distress associated with traumatic memories. It involves focusing on traumatic or triggering memories while performing specific eye movements, guided by a therapist. This process is believed to help the brain process and integrate these memories, reducing their emotional impact. It's a technique that many have found effective, but it's most important that whatever approach you take, it feels right for you.
That sounds promising, but also a bit scary. I'm not sure if I'm ready to face those memories yet.

Feeling scared or unsure about facing traumatic memories is completely natural. It's a significant step, and being ready for it is crucial. It's okay to take your time and work towards feeling safe and prepared. Your well-being and sense of safety are the most important things. When or if you decide you're ready, we can explore these options further, but only at a pace that feels comfortable for you.
Thank you. I think I need some time to think about it. But it's good to know there are options.

Of course, take all the time you need. This journey is yours, and it's about moving at a pace that honors your feelings and needs. I'm here to support you, provide information, and help you navigate your options whenever you're ready. Feel free to reach out whenever you'd like to talk more or have any questions.
I really appreciate that. I'll definitely keep it in mind. Thanks for listening and helping me understand more about this.
You're very welcome. Remember, you're not alone in this, and there's support available whenever you're ready to take the next steps. Take care of yourself, and don't hesitate to reach out.

questionText: At a friend's house, we had some drinks and watched some television. He got up and went to bed. I felt sick. He came out to see if I was okay, and I said no. I said I wanted to go home, and he told me to come lay down. As I laid down on the bed, he started touching me. A friend called me, then I able to leave.
answerText: I am so sorry that this happened to you and am so glad that you were able to get away.  Your body is yours and yours alone.  I would highly recommend that you find a therapist who specializes in treating trauma in order to help you to heal from your ordeal.

messages.content: Hello, how are you doing, how can I help you today?
I've been feeling really upset and confused lately. Something happened at a friend's house that's been bothering me a lot.
I'm truly sorry to hear that you're going through a difficult time. It's important that you know you're not alone. Would you feel comfortable sharing more about what happened?

Yeah, I think I need to talk about it. We were just hanging out, having some drinks and watching TV. Then, I started feeling sick. My friend went to bed, but came out to check on me when I got worse. I told him I wanted to go home.
It sounds like you were in a vulnerable state, and it was good that initially, your friend showed concern for your well-being. What happened after you said you wanted to go home?
He suggested I lay down for a bit. But after I did, he started touching me in a way I didn't consent to. I was really scared and didn't know what to do.

I am so sorry that you experienced that. It's completely understandable to feel scared and violated in such a situation. Your feelings are valid, and what happened was not your fault. Your body is yours, and you have the right to your boundaries respected at all times.
Thank you. I've been blaming myself and it's been hard to talk about it. I managed to leave because a friend called me. That call felt like a lifeline at that moment.

It's a relief to hear that you had a way out of that situation, and it was very brave of you to take that step. It's common to have mixed feelings and self-blame after such incidents, but I want to reiterate, what happened is not your fault. Have you been able to share this with anyone else?
No, you're the first person I've talked to about it. I've been too ashamed to bring it up to anyone else.

Sharing something so personal and painful takes a lot of courage. I'm here for you, and I'm glad you felt you could trust me with this. If you're open to it, I would highly recommend finding a therapist who specializes in treating trauma. They can provide you with the support and guidance needed to heal from this ordeal.
I think I might need that. It's been really hard to cope, and I don't want to feel this way anymore.

Seeking help is a strong and positive step towards healing. I can help you look for resources or therapists who specialize in this area. It's important to take this journey at your own pace, and I'll be here to support you along the way.
Thank you, that would be really helpful. I just want to start feeling like myself again.
Of course. Together, we'll work on finding the right support for you. Remember, healing is a process, and it's okay to take it one step at a time. You're not alone in this.

questionText: At school, it feels like I've lost all my friends, and I've been really weird with my sleeping patterns. I used to cut myself, and I really want to again, but I change in the locker rooms because I don’t want anybody to see. I get ticked off easy and overreact. At night, I’m very depressed and listen to sad music and all that sort of stuff. Please help me. I just want to be happy again, and I feel like I’m starting to fake a smile at school.
answerText: As silly as it may sound, making sure that we are getting the right amount of *restful* sleep is very important when we are feeling low.  The reason for this is the lack of proper sleep significantly affects our ability to problem solve and critically evaluate our situation and can lead to a domino effect in our thinking.  I know you feel that you may be losing your friendships, but what are the facts that have led to this belief? Really ask yourself, "are they facts?" or are they your perspective on events.  In regards to your coping behaviours at night, it sounds very isolating and also very silenced.  As opposed to the sad music, why not try all music, allowing yourself to experience the wide breadth of emotions that are circling within you.  One of the other recommendations I would make would be to try and journal about some of those thoughts and fears in order to release them in a positively cathartic way. Some of the behaviours that you have mentioned are a bit more significant, though and I would recommend speaking with someone directly in the near future.

messages.content: Hello, how are you doing, how can I help you today?

I've been feeling really down lately. At school, it feels like I've lost all my friends, and my sleeping patterns are all over the place. I used to cut myself, and the urge is coming back. I'm trying to hide it, especially in the locker rooms. I get easily upset and overreact to things. At night, it's worse; I'm very depressed and listen to sad music. I just want to be happy again, but I feel like I’m starting to fake a smile at school.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a tough time. It sounds like you're feeling quite isolated and struggling with some intense emotions. The fact that you're reaching out for help is a brave step. Let's talk about your sleep first. It's really important, though it might sound a bit simple, to try and get restful sleep. Lack of proper sleep can really affect our mood and ability to deal with problems. Have you noticed any patterns in your sleep that might be contributing to how you're feeling?
Yeah, I guess my sleep is really erratic. I stay up late listening to music or just thinking, and then I'm exhausted at school. It's like I can't turn off my brain.

It sounds like your mind is very active at night, which is keeping you from getting the restful sleep you need. Have you tried any methods to help you relax and prepare for sleep, such as limiting screen time before bed or trying some relaxation techniques?
Not really, I usually have my phone with me until I try to sleep. I haven't tried relaxation techniques either.

It might be helpful to create a calming bedtime routine. Limiting screen time before bed can help signal to your brain that it's time to wind down. Relaxation techniques, like deep breathing or guided imagery, can also be very effective. Now, about feeling like you've lost your friends, what makes you feel that way? Have there been specific events, or is it more about how you're interpreting things?
I think it's a bit of both. There were a couple of incidents where I felt left out, and since then, I just feel like they don't want me around.

It sounds like those incidents really hurt you and have had a lasting impact on how you view your friendships. It's natural to feel hurt when we feel excluded or left out. Sometimes our interpretation of these events can amplify those feelings. Have you had a chance to talk to your friends about how you've been feeling?
No, I haven't. I'm afraid it'll just make things awkward or they'll deny it and make me feel worse.

It's understandable to feel scared about opening up, especially when you're already feeling vulnerable. Communication can be really challenging but also very healing. It might help to write down what you want to say first. This could help clarify your thoughts and feelings. Also, consider the music you're listening to at night. Music can deeply affect our emotions. Have you thought about listening to a variety of music, not just sad songs?
I haven't thought about that. I guess I just gravitated towards music that reflects how I feel. Maybe I should try something more uplifting?

Exploring different types of music could be a good way to allow yourself to experience a range of emotions. Music has the power to uplift and shift our mood. And about the urge to self-harm, it's really important to find healthier ways to cope with these feelings. Journaling might be a positive outlet for you. It can be a way to express and process your emotions safely. How do you feel about giving it a try?
I used to keep a diary, but I stopped. Maybe I could start again. It might help to get some of these thoughts out of my head.

That sounds like a great idea. Journaling can be very cathartic. Remember, it's okay to seek help and you're not alone in this. These feelings can be overwhelming, but there are ways to cope and people who want to support you. How do you feel about what we've discussed today?
I feel a bit better, actually. Like maybe there's a way through this. I'll try the music and journaling, and maybe I'll even talk to my friends. Thanks for listening and for the advice.

I'm glad to hear that you're feeling a bit more hopeful. Remember, it's a process, and it's okay to take small steps. I'm here to support you. Please feel free to reach out anytime you need to talk. Take care.
